Lab 01: Intro Computing for Data Science

Overview

This lab serves to level the playing field when it comes to basic computer literacy. For everyone to succeed, everyone must be presented the same information. Not all students coming into this class have had the opportunity to work with computers often, and even if you have, you may not be uses to using computers in the way that we will be doing so in this class.

Computers are not like phones, where apps 1-click install to a location you don‚Äôt need to care about, and ‚Äújust work‚Äù. To set yourself up for success in school, research and professional life it is well worth your time to take a moment and look at how to use a computer in a professional setting.

Instructions

This is a follow-along lab. The activities and questions that are asked are designed to have you learn or practice something, without the lecture part. This lets you more actively participate in your learning. Some parts you are asked to do on your own, such as reading a short article, or watching & listening to a short external video. Other times you will be following along as the instructor demonstrates how to accomplish a task.

Often you will be asked to Google something. This is not a cop-out on my part as a way to not write instructions, learning how to effectively search for information on the internet is one of the course objectives. So we‚Äôll practice this activity often.

üëâ Do this

Grey/Blue boxes like this are instructions for you to do something.

‚úèÔ∏è Check your knowledge

Green boxes like this indicates that this is a question for you to answer. Pay attention to where you should be answering these questions at. E.g. Canvas, Rstudio or somewhere else. This will be specified in the submission instructions section.

Submission Instructions

Write your answers and submit your screenshots to the lab assignment ‚Äúquiz‚Äù in Canvas.

Computer Operating Systems

Review the Wikipedia entry on Operating Systems

Specifically pay attention to 1) the image to the right, 2) the first sentence and 3) the last sentence before the ‚ÄúContents‚Äù block.

‚úèÔ∏è Check your knowledge
  1. In a sentence, in your own words, what is an OS, and list the four most commonly used OS‚Äôs.
  2. What OS are you using? If the computer you are using to fill out this lab is different than the one you typically use, what is the OS you typically use? Is your lab neighbor using the same OS as you?
  3. Why do you think you need to know this information?

File types

File types are also known as file formats, is the way computers store (or encode) information.

Filename extensions are the little suffixes added to the file name of a computer file. You may be familiar with extensions such as .docx, .htmlor .pdf . These explicitly tell your computer what program is used to open the file. The commonality these all have is that they have a period . between the file name, and the file extension.

Depending on your OS‚Äôs settings, sometimes these file extension will not be shown in the file name.

However, your computer will also show a specific icon for file type.

üëâ Do this

Google ‚ÄúFile type icons‚Äù, select ‚Äúimages‚Äù.

‚úèÔ∏è Check your knowledge
  1. Which file type icons do you recognize? Take a screen shot of a few and add them to your submission.

‚ö†Ô∏èIf the file type extension gets removed from the file name, it can potentially corrupt the file. Sometimes you can rename the file and put the extension back on, sometimes this will not work.

File organization

File organization and naming are powerful weapons against chaos.
‚ÄìJenny Bryan

There are many ways to organize your files, you may find yourself changing your organizational method part way through your academic career. This is normal and expected. While you don‚Äôt need to be organized, your future self (and anyone you collaborate with) will find it very helpful. Payoffs accumulate as your projects get more complex.

File names

üëâ Do this

Review Jenny‚Äôs slide deck.

Content in this section is credited to Naming things by Jenny Bryan.

TLDR;

üõë myabstract.docx
üõë Joe‚Äôs Filenames Use Spaces and Punctuation.xlsx
üõë figure 1.png
üõë fig 2.png
üõë JW7d^(2sl@deletethisandyourcareerisoverWx2*.txt ‚úÖ 2014-06-08_abstract-for-sla.docx
‚úÖjoes-filenames-are-getting-better.xlsx
‚úÖfig01_scatterplot-talk-length-vs-interest.png
‚úÖfig02_histogram-talk-attendance.png
‚úÖ1986-01-28_raw-data-from-challenger-o-rings.txt

Three principles for file names

  1. Machine readable
    • avoid spaces, punctuation, accented characters, case sensitivity
  2. Human readable
    • name contains information on content
  3. Plays well with default ordering
    • put something numeric first, use proper dates, left pad numbers with zero

Text

You may be used to using Sentence case such as

Math 185 homework 1.docx
Donatello CV as of Feb 2021.pdf

These are human readable because we can figure out what the file is about based on the name. But they still violates principle #1 & 3.

Revised names:

hw01_math185_rdonatello.docx
2021-02_CV

Left pad numbers with zeros

This means to use 01 instead of 1.

if you don‚Äôt left pad, you get this:

10_final-figs-for-publication.R
1_data-cleaning.R
2_fit-model.R

which is just sad

Use YYYY-MM-DD for standard dates

File locations

For the love of all that is holy, DON‚ÄôT SAVE FILES IN YOUR DOWNLOADS FOLDER!

I had to get that out of my system.

A file path is like directions for your computer on how to find your file.

üëâ Do this

Look at the examples of file paths on different systems in the linked Wikipedia article.

  • A back slash \ indicates a sub-folder.
  • Not all places that are easy to access using a mouse have a short path
    • C:\Users\rdonatello\Desktop\New folder
  • Long paths don‚Äôt always indicate lack of organization
    • C:\Users\rdonatello\Box\CHC All\01. Projects Active\SNAP-Ed on Campuses (SP6485201, 02)\08. Research and Evaluation\02. Data Analysis\shared reports
üëâ Do this

Start to create good habits for yourself by saving files in an organized manner.

  1. Decide on a location for files associate with this class. This CANNOT be your downloads folder.
  2. Create a class folder, and a homework subfolder
  3. Download this file and save it in your homework subfolder. Give it a file name that meets the three principles listed above.
‚úèÔ∏è Check your knowledge
  1. Submit a screenshot of your class folder with downloaded file.
  2. Write out the full path, including file name to the downloaded file.
  • How to find a path to a file in Windows 10
  • How to find a path to a file on Mac

Install Programs

Data is often stored in a spreadsheet format (.csv, .xls, .xlsx) and so you need a way on your local machine to open and view these files. Google Sheets does not have the full functionality as a program like Microsoft Excel. Mac Numbers also does not always play well with others.

Good news is that MS Excel (and the whole Office suite) is free for students.

üëâ Do this

Follow (these instructions)[https://support.csuchico.edu/TDClient/1984/Portal/KB/ArticleDet?ID=8738] to install Excel on your computer.

If you do not have a Mac or Windows computer, come talk me about an alternative.

You will start learning Excel next week!

‚úèÔ∏è Check your knowledge
  1. Submit a screenshot showing the Excel program open on your computer.
